title: Review & setlist: Dropkick Murphys come on strong, avert disaster at soggy Suffolk Downs
author: Marc Hirsh
bullets: Dropkick Murphys performed at the Seisiún festival in Boston after a two-hour rain delay.
The festival was delayed due to a thunderstorm, which turned Suffolk Downs into a marsh.
The Dropkick Murphys delivered a vibrant performance, emphasizing community with songs against fascism.

title: Bill Belichick explains ‘simple’ reason why he decided to ban Patriots scout at UNC
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bill Belichick banned a Patriots scout from UNC, citing lack of welcome at the Patriots' facility.
Belichick's decision marks a continuing tense relationship between him and the Patriots since his 2023 departure.
Patriots coach Mike Vrabel acknowledged the ban but stated focus remains on the team, not scouting conflicts.

title: 6 takeaways from Patriots’ 20-13 loss to Raiders
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The Patriots lost to the Raiders 20-13 after a promising first half, failing to score effectively in the second.
Drake Maye threw for 287 yards with one touchdown and one interception, struggling with turnovers after halftime.
Patriots rookie left tackle Will Campbell had a challenging debut, allowing a strip-sack and committing two false starts.

title: Watch: Dropkick Murphys blast Trump, but stump for a longshot New England candidate
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Dropkick Murphys' Ken Casey criticized Donald Trump during their set at the Seisiún Irish music festival in Boston.
Casey endorsed Graham Platner, a 40-year-old Marine Corps veteran challenging GOP Sen. Susan Collins of Maine.
Platner aims to bring change, opposing Trumpism and criticizing the Democratic establishment, as covered by Eugene Scott.

title: Tenants move into first downtown apartment in Wu’s office-residential conversion program
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: The first project in Mayor Wu's office-to-residential conversion program opened at 281 Franklin St., offering 15 new apartments.
The program launched in 2023 and received an additional $15 million in state funding in 2024 for more conversions.
Developer Adam Burns cited tax incentives as crucial for converting five office floors to apartments, addressing high vacancy rates.

title: Disciplinary cases tripled at Harvard due to pro-Palestine protests, student newspaper reports
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Harvard disciplined 90 students for participating in pro-Palestine protests during the 2023-2024 academic year.
58 students were placed on probation for protests, marking the highest since 2017-2018, 31 others were admonished.
Five initial suspensions for a Harvard Yard protest were reduced to probation after faculty review criticized harsh actions.

title: Photos: Music, Guinness, and lots of rain at Day 1 of Seisiún Irish music festival in Boston
author: Boston.com
bullets: Severe weather on Saturday couldn't stop the new Seisiún Irish music festival at Suffolk Downs in Boston.
The Dropkick Murphys, The Hold Steady, and other bands performed despite a rain delay.
Festival attendees enjoyed Guinness and entertainment while wearing Irish-themed attire amid storms.

title: Fear and Loathing in New England
author: Lauren Daley
bullets: Ralph Steadman's retrospective 'And Another Thing' is on view at Bates College Museum of Art in Lewiston, Maine, until Oct. 11.
Steadman recalls a 1970 incident with Hunter S. Thompson in Newport involving psilocybin, attempted yacht vandalism, and flare guns.
The exhibition showcases 149 pieces, covering Steadman’s 60-year career, including collaborations with Hunter S. Thompson and political cartoons.

title: New report outlines how many people might lose SNAP in Greater Boston under Trump bill
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: About 40,000 Boston-area SNAP recipients, including 9,600 legally present immigrants, risk losing benefits under Trump's bill.
The One Big Beautiful Bill tightens SNAP and Medicaid requirements and shifts 75% of SNAP administrative costs to Massachusetts.
Greater Boston has 361,473 SNAP cases, with major reliance in cities like Lawrence, Brockton, and Boston, affecting food security.

title: 3 takeaways from the Revolution’s 3-2 loss vs. the Chicago Fire
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: New England Revolution's playoff hopes fade after a 3-2 loss to the Chicago Fire.
Chicago Fire scored early goals by Jonathan Bamba and Philip Zinckernagel, creating a decisive lead.
New England remains 11 points from the playoff line with only five games left in the season.
